stem: A 62-year-old male is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to sepsis. Based on the provided information, select the TWO most likely causes of the patient's ARDS, the MOST likely condition the patient is experiencing as a result of ARDS, and the TWO most appropriate interventions.

rationale.correct: Sepsis is a major cause of ARDS due to the systemic inflammatory response. Increased alveolar-capillary permeability is a hallmark of ARDS, leading to pulmonary edema. Prone positioning improves oxygenation by redistributing lung perfusion and ventilation. Low tidal volume ventilation prevents ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) by minimizing alveolar overdistension.
rationale.incorrect: Aspiration pneumonia can cause ARDS, but sepsis is the primary diagnosis in this case. Hypovolemia is unlikely in ARDS; fluid overload is more typical. High tidal volume ventilation can worsen lung injury. Supplemental oxygen alone will not address the underlying pathology of ARDS. Nebulized bronchodilators are more appropriate for conditions like asthma or COPD exacerbations.
clinicalPearls: Prone positioning can significantly improve oxygenation in ARDS patients.
Low tidal volume ventilation is crucial to prevent VILI in ARDS.
Sepsis-induced ARDS requires both respiratory support and treatment of the underlying infection.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus solely on improving oxygenation without considering the underlying cause of ARDS or the importance of lung-protective ventilation strategies.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize identifying the root cause of ARDS and select interventions that address both oxygenation and lung protection to prevent further lung injury.

mnemonic.title: ARDS
mnemonic.expansion: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: Alveolar damage, Reduced compliance, Dyspnea, Severe hypoxemia

reviewUnits.title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
reviewUnits.content: ARDS is a severe inflammatory lung condition characterized by increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to pulmonary edema and hypoxemia. Management focuses on treating the underlying cause and providing supportive care, including mechanical ventilation with lung-protective strategies.

itemContext.sbar: 0700: Patient John Doe, 62-year-old male, admitted to ICU at 0600 with ARDS secondary to sepsis. Oxygen saturation is 88% on FiO2 60%. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Initial ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 58 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L. Patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Blood cultures are pending. Currently on norepinephrine for blood pressure support. 0715: Increased FiO2 to 70% per protocol. Assess breath sounds every 2 hours. Continue monitoring vital signs and ABGs. Dr. Smith is aware of the patient's status.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 0600: Patient admitted to ICU with respiratory distress. SpO2 85% on room air. Patient appears anxious and is using accessory muscles. 0615: Placed on 100% FiO2 via non-rebreather mask. SpO2 improved to 90%. 0630: Patient intubated due to worsening respiratory status. Placed on mechanical ventilation with tidal volume 400 mL, rate 16, FiO2 60%, PEEP 5 cm H2O. 0700: ABG drawn. Norepinephrine infusion started at 5 mcg/min. 0730: Initiated sepsis protocol per physician order.
